captions.text:
It's a tale as old as time, or at least, as
old as dogs. You let Fido out the door, and

immediately he's munching on the grass like
it's covered in bacon grease. Maybe that dog

threw it up later, more likely it didn't,
either way, it begs the question: why do dogs
eat grass?

One commonly held theory is dogs use grass
as the natural remedy to induce their own

vomiting. The idea here is that Fido might
start grazing when he's feeling gassy or there's

something else going on in his digestive system
that he wants to get rid of. But so far, there's

actually not too much evidence for that, although
eating grass can lead to vomiting, that typically

only happens to about 25% of dogs. Instead,
the simplest explanation is that dogs eat

grass because they like it. Let's face it,
the average dog will attempt to eat pretty

much anything given the chance, and keep in
mind that wolves and coyotes and other wild
canines regularly dabble in plant eating.

Unlike cats who are purely carnivorous, dogs
are omnivores. So not only will they scavenge

anything if they're hungry enough, including
fruits and berries and grass, but many wild

dogs also hunt herbivores and devour their
stomach contents whole.

So some experts believe that grass eating
may be a natural way for domesticated dogs

to have a varied diet. Now, if your dog is
eating a lot of grass, he or she might have
some kind of nutritional deficiency.

Dogs, like us, don't have the enzymes to break
down cellulose, the main energy source in

grass. So they may just be grazing for a source
of fiber. But some grasses can provide decent

amounts of minerals, like phosphorous and
calcium and potassium, which might explain

why some dogs are known to only eat certain
kinds of grass.

Either way, a little grass-eating can be normal
and harmless, assuming the grass wasn't just

hosed down with a bunch of herbicides and
pesticides.

But if you're worried about your dog's nutrition
or digestion, you can always ask your vet

for advice on changes to your pup's diet.
You can also be thankful that they're going

for the grass instead of the poop, because
that's a thing that happens! But that's for
another episode!

Thanks for asking! Especially to our Subbable
subscribers who get these Quick Questions

episodes a little earlier than the rest of
you. If you have a quick question for us,

let us know on facebook or twitter or in the
comments below, and don't forget to go to
youtube.com/scishow and subscribe!

Iˇm a little late, but to the dudes who want to know why they eat poop : 
it´s because there a still a lot of nurishment in feaces due to no 
digestive system ever being close to 100% effecient. Not only that, but 
whatever nutrients that are left in the turd has already been broken down 
and is (perhaps a little paradoxically) marvelously digestable. Dogs are 
opportunists and have evolved to eat as much as they can, of whatever they 
can, because they might have to wait a long time ´til they get their next 
chow-down.﻿

comments.author: Mitchie Anne

comments.text:
At 0:15, Hank misuses the term "to beg the question."  Many people 
mistakenly think that "to beg the question" means something like "to compel 
one to ask the question" "to make one wonder."  In fact, the term means 
that you assume the answer to the question as part of your proof of the 
answer to the question, essentially engaging in circular reasoning.

For example, if one argued "all dogs have four legs because all dogs are 
quadrupeds" or "honey is good for you because honey is a healthy treat" one 
would be begging the question.

Just saying...﻿

comments.text:
They eat particular blades of grass that are richer in B17 Nitrilocides 
(Leatrile) than other blades of grass. Dogs can smell it in certain blades 
of grass. They do this every so often because it's lacking in their diet. 
The same way other wild species will seek out salt every so often. Not all 
dogs do this, which can be for a number of reasons: Some may not have the 
instinctive ability to know that such an important ingredient is missing 
from their processed food, so they don't associate the small of certain 
blades of grass as the remedy for them feeling slightly malnutritioned. Or 
they can't smell it in the grass. Or their bodies are better at processing 
and storing B17. Or they that B17 is abundant in their particular food 
products which could be varied. (Organic foods will have higher chance of 
containing B17 but possibly not in that particular organic source). I heard 
that scientists were locked up and stripped of their credibilities in the 
USA for trying to publish their research on B17. Not saying that's a fact. 
Just 3rd hand information. The information is on youtube and of course the 
web as a whole.

Apparently nearly all Bears that live in zoo's develop cancer. With no 
cases of cancer identified in wild Bears. This is said to be because of the 
diet bears are fed in zoo's. Where their diet in the wild contained rich 
amounts of B17 and their captive food containing none or very little at 
all. And there's a Himalayas nation of a million people who not only have 
among the longest, if not thee longest life spans, but they have never had 
a single case of cancer among them. They eat a nut which has the highest 
concentration of B17 in the world. They apparently have annual festivals 
where they turn this nut into a purple porridge which is their national 
dish.﻿

comments.text:
My dogs are out for a walk and after running around like a pair of mental 
idiots for a while they will start to eat grass, I have found that this is 
because they are thirsty and grass is the only way they can get water. Once 
I get the water bottle out and they have a drink, the grass-eating stops 
(yes, my dogs drink directly from water bottles).﻿
comments.author: wierdwesterner

comments.text:
+VioletVixen I use a 1 litre bottle with sports cap that you have to 
squeeze to get the water out of. I tip it upside down and hold it so the 
mouthpiece is below their chin level and pointing towards the floor (if 
they drink with their heads up they tend to just cough it up again as the 
water is going down the wrong way) and they will lick the mouthpiece, so I 
start squeezing. Either that or I will just stream it to the floor and they 
will drink it on it's way down through the side of their mouth, they won't 
get much but it will get them enough to stop them feeling thirsty.

comments.text:
As far as I know, cats eat grass or plants to induce vomiting. It's their 
way of getting rid of fur balls in their stomach. Even if they haven't 
eaten live prey, they do it instinctually. Don't want fur blocking their 
digestive track ;) So don't worry about that.
Btw, don't give animals cheese, milk or chocolate. Adult animals are 
lactose intolerant and you may kill them. Only adult humans have managed to 
digest milk, but not even all humans. Don't believe the stereotypes of cats 
and milk, mice and cheese etc!﻿

comments.author: devilfoxe

comments.text:
The lines of herbivore/Omnivore/carnivore are actually a lot more blurred 
than what people may think. We've seen carnivores that will eat plants and 
even fungi and herbivores that eat meat, this includes cows, horses and 
deer, each having been documented eating meat.

Words like herbivore/omnivore/carnivore really only cover what species 
typically eat as to opposed to what they can and can't eat. If the latter 
held true, the world would be populated by a lot more omnivores.﻿

comments.author: Barry Wheeler

comments.text:
My cat loves eating grass. It appears she mainly does it as a way to clean 
her teeth like a toothbrush. The majority is left unswallowed, but chewed. 
She does not do it to induce vomiting (in fact not eating grass seems to 
make her vomit more often), and her faeces seem unaffected. I suspect it is 
more like an enjoyable habit for her... very enjoyable, sometimes she wont 
come inside unless I brink in a chunk of grass for her to munch. She 
prefers the types of grass with more silicon in the leaf structure (further 
enhancing the toothbrush theory), which has put my indoor bamboo at a 
severe disadvantage.

My dog on the other hand obviously does it as a source of fiber. She will 
eat more grass when her poos are runny, and less grass when her poos are 
solid. The grass in her faeces usually seems relatively undigested.﻿
